results.title: Snapshot = Day after Halloween = Day before Halloween [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Simon Wincer, Antony Ginnane, William Fayman, Barbi Taylor and Australian International Film Corporation
results.brief_description: For his film debut director Simon Wincer chose to tread the well-chartered territory of the horror thriller, in which the life for an innocent character is irretrievably changed through a combination of naivety and bad encounters. Angela, a young hairdresser with modelling ambitions, is talked into posing nude for a photo in order to attract attention. Soon enough, the attention is transformed in stalking, complete with the discovery of a pig’s head in her bed. Of the sleazy producer, the eccentric magazine producer and the clingy ex-boyfriend — who wants Angela dead and why? Reference: Greg Kerr ‘Australian Film’ (Scott Murray ed.) Oxford University Press, 1995: p. 47.

results.title: All that jazz [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Bob Fosse, Robert A Aurthur and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Joe Gideon is a chain-smoking, pill popping workaholic obsessed with producing, directing and choreographing a Broadway musical while womanising and editing his latest film (actually Fosse’s own film “Lenny”). This semi-autobiographical musical drama is framed by Gideon’s conversations with a mysterious figure of nemesis the “Lady in White”. Following Gideon’s heart attack, the film assumes a surreal hallucinatory logic. Not only does Fosse borrow freely from the European classics “8 1/2” and “The Seventh seal” but he inverts the showbiz and life affirming “That’s entertainment” ethos of the traditional musical. Cast includes Roy Scheider, Jessica Lange, Ann Reinking and John Lithgow. Awards: Winner, Best Art Direction, Costume Design, Editing, Best Score, Academy Awards, 1979.

results.title: Swingers
results.creator_credit: Doug Liman, Victor Simpkins, Miramax Films and Independent Pictures
results.brief_description: A hip, urban comedy of manners about male friendship, dating and the fantastically labyrinthine rules of how to stay cool in LA. Directed by Doug Liman (Go, The Bourne Identity), this film catapulted into the spotlight actors Jon Favreau (who also wrote the screenplay) and Vince Vaughn. Mike (Favreau), an out of work actor and comedian, is lovesick for his long-term girlfriend who he hasn’t heard from in six months. Buoyed in his misery by friends Trent, Rob and Sue, Mike is taken to a slew of groovy LA bars and parties in the hope that he’ll meet a babe and be jolted out of his despair. Trent (Vaughn) is Mike’s most confident and smooth talking friend, a sartorial charmer who has a way with the ladies and is constantly on the make. Mike struggles with the convoluted courtship rules, whilst battling his extensive self-doubts and self-consciousness. “Swingers” works as a sharp satire of the LA scene where bit actors scrape by on the glory of call-backs for pilots and former glories are regurgitated in the hope of getting lucky in love. With a warm, energetic quality, and a talky, funny script, the film regales the audience with memorable characters and hilarious scenarios.

results.title: You can count on me
results.creator_credit: Kenneth Lonergan, John N. Hart, Larry Meistrich, Jeffrey Sharp, Barbara de Fina, Hart Sharp Entertainment, Cappa Productions and Shooting Gallery
results.brief_description: You can count on me is a family reunion drama that contains impressive performances full of nuance and has an adroit observational tone. The original screenplay (by director Kenneth Lonergan) veers away from cliche and pat conclusions, imbuing the characters with a realistic quality. Sammy and Terry are orphaned at a young age when their parents are killed in a car accident. As adults, the siblings are estranged, having made divergent choices. Sammy is a single parent with an eight-year-old son, Rudy, living in the house she was brought up in, working in a bank. She lives by a strict moral code, bound by religion and duty, but is entirely capable of hypocrisy and self-delusion. Terry, by contrast, is a wild loner, full of rage, self-destructive by nature but charming in his own humorous way. He doesn’t believe in Sammy’s ordered conservative life and inadvertently challenges this, creating chaos with his presence. It is Terry and Rudy’s strengthening relationship that acts as a catalyst, causing an irrevocable torrent of truths that upend the family dynamics. The personal and familial dilemmas contained within the script are identifiable and the film sensitively deals with themes of oppression and personal choice. Cast includes: Laura Linney, Matthew Broderick, Mark Ruffalo, Rory Culkin.

results.title: The Wizard of Oz [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Victor Fleming, Mervyn LeRoy and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: This 50th Anniversary Commemorative Edition of the “Wizard of Oz” is as it was originally released in 1939, including the Kansas scenes in warm sepia tones. Featuring film clips and reconstructed musical numbers cut from the original film, this beautifully restored technicolour print is a tribute to the popularity of “The Wizard of Oz” with adults and children alike.

results.title: The Defiant ones
results.creator_credit: Stanley Kramer and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: Two convicts - one black, one white - escape across country chained together. Initially the yard of chain shackles two bitter enemies but gradually a bond grows between them. Dramatically and cinematically this is probably the most satisfying of Kramer’s “message” pictures but, although free of sentimentality and polemics, the notion of universal brotherhood is perhaps too simplistic to carry much conceptual interest. Winner of two Academy Awards (1958). Cast includes Tony Curtis and Sidney Poitier.

results.title: Mary Poppins [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Robert Stevenson, Walt Disney and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Based on the “Mary Poppins” books by P.L. Travers, this Walt Disney masterpiece stars Julie Andrews, Dick Van Dyke, David Tomlinson and Glynis Johns. Disney successfully melds live action sequences with stop-animation, cell animation, song and dance routines. Set in 1910, the story is that of a stultified British family being run with cold efficiency by a draconian father, who pays no mind to his two children, Jane and Michael, and their suffragette mother. The children attempt to gain their parents’ attention by unsettling a slew of nannies, until Mary Poppins arrives to save them. Poppins has magical powers that enchant the children and she eventually brings the family back together, with the aid of her friend Bert (van Dyke). Charming songs include “Chim-Chim-Cher-Ee” and “Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious.” The film was nominated for thirteen Academy Awards, winning five including Best Picture. Screen debut of Julie Andrews, who won the Oscar for Best Actress.

results.title: Monty Python's life of Brian [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Terry Jones, John Goldstone and HandMade Films
results.brief_description: Iconic comedy from the Monty Python team, “The Life of Brian” ridicules Christianity, organised religion, politics, underground subversives and Jesus Christ. From birth, the unfortunate and guileless Brian is mistaken for the Son of God and dogged by his nearby presence as well as being pestered by his shrewish mother. The Monty Python crew each play numerous roles within the film, creating an anarchic madcap spoof of Biblical films and religious epics. With several musical interludes, including “Always look on the bright side of life” (sung at the crucifixion) the writers slay many sacred cows in the name of comedy. Blissfully sacrilegious and completely irreverent, “Life of Brian” was banned in several countries, but nevertheless garnered cult status and is regarded by many as the funniest of the Monty Python’s feature films. Also features Spike Milligan and Beatle George Harrison, whose company produced the film.

constellations_other.name: Swords, sandals and lightning bolts
constellations_other.description: In Thor: Love and Thunder, Russell Crowe plays one of the most recogniseable gods in the pantheon – Zeus. His scenes lampoon his Oscar-winning role in Gladiator, one of the most recognised films in a classic genre.

results.title: Desperately seeking Susan [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Susan Seidelman, Midge Sanford, Sarah Pillsbury and Orion Pictures Corporation
results.brief_description: Susan (Madonna) is a free spirit: she lives fast and breaks hearts. After walking out on a high roller in Atlantic City - taking a priceless pair of Egyptian earrings with her - she returns to New York, only to read a newspaper headline describing his murder. She doesn’t realise the killer is now on the trail of the earrings, a trail which will inevitably lead him to her. Meanwhile, bored housewife, Roberta (Rosanna Arquette) is idly reading the Personal Ads. “Desperately seeking Susan” announces a lover’s plea, and she wishes someone would desperately look for her. Susan makes the rendezvous and so does Roberta. And from then on their lives intertwine in a high-speed drama of fantasy and reality. Exchanging clothes, identities - and men, even the murderer doesn’t know which Susan he’s desperate to meet. Cast also includes Aidan Quinn.

results.title: Body of evidence
results.creator_credit: Uli Edel, Dino De Laurentiis and De Laurentiis Entertainment Group
results.brief_description: An erotic thriller and murder mystery, “Body of evidence” is probably best remembered for the brouhaha surrounding the sado-masochistic sex games played out before the camera by actors Madonna and Willem Dafoe. Madonna plays a beautiful, sexually aggressive seductress named Rebecca who has a penchant for perilous peccadillos preferably conducted with wealthy men of poor heart condition. When one partner dies in the throes of passion, leaving Rebecca eight million dollars, she is charged with murder. Dafoe plays Frank Dulaney, an ambitious attorney who takes on the case, and despite being uncertain of Rebecca’s innocence, is soon drawn into an amorous relationship that belies his history as a loyal family man. A courtroom drama, not entirely dissimilar in structure to “Witness for the prosecution” (Hitchcock, 1957), this film was released in the wake of the hit “Basic instinct”, but despite matching its salaciousness (and silliness), failed to replicate its success at the box-office. Contains explicit sex scenes and situations but has quite predictably, a morally conservative outcome.

Madonna plays a beautiful, sexually aggressive seductress named Rebecca who has a penchant for perilous peccadillos preferably conducted with wealthy men of poor heart condition. When one partner dies in the throes of passion, leaving Rebecca eight million dollars, she is charged with murder. Dafoe plays Frank Dulaney, an ambitious attorney who takes on the case, and despite being uncertain of Rebecca’s innocence, is soon drawn into an amorous relationship that belies his history as a loyal family man. A courtroom drama, not entirely dissimilar in structure to “Witness for the prosecution” (Hitchcock, 1957), this film was released in the wake of the hit “Basic instinct”, but despite matching its salaciousness (and silliness), failed to replicate its success at the box-office. Contains explicit sex scenes and situations but has quite predictably, a morally conservative outcome.
